title: WAAAX wobble has investors wondering if this time is different
text:
"It looks easy, because they keep going up, but whenever you get the sense it’s easy that’s usually a sign it’s not too far from reality striking.

"In the very short term, you never know whether this is a blip before they go onward and upward again, but certainly it’s come from a renewed focus on the valuations."

Trading at 150 times earnings, "you’ve got to be spotless or you get a retracement of the rating," Mr Black warned.

WAAAX stocks have rewarded backers with their relentless ascent, but growth names have shown a tendency to deliver painful drawdowns when negative events arise. The WAAAX basket has risen an average of 350 per cent over the two years to September 30 and trades on an average multiple of more than 100 times earnings.

Growth outlook

Speedcast International, for example, fell 40 per cent in July after a downgrade.

Although the economic data still presents the global manufacturing sector as being in recession, bonds have sold off sharply in advanced economies, including in Australia where the yield on the 10-year government bond has increased to 1.17 per cent from 0.88 per cent in August.

"Even though the growth outlook still seems gloomy, the easing of trade tensions between the US and China and some hope around Brexit has been enough to shift sentiment and put a floor under the bond market," said Sage Capital managing director Sean Fenton.

Advertisement

"Throw in some short reports and regulatory concerns on stocks that were beginning to be priced for perfection and it’s not surprising to see some rotation from growth to value."

What's unclear, Mr Fenton said, is whether this is the start of a new market dynamic or a three-day trade. "For the rotation to have legs we will need to see business confidence improve substantially, which probably requires a more definitive trade deal. The underlying fabric of the global economy remains intact and money is free so an improvement in confidence could certainly drive an upswing in activity."

In the background, WeWork's escalation from IPO hopeful to needing a rescue to avert a cash crunch has underscored how quickly the optics of growth can change.

Acquired rather than being floated

Federation Asset Management chairman Greg Bundy pointed to WeWork’s speculated IPO valuation of about $US40 billion and reported speculation that Softbank has valued it at $US8 billion.

"You would have to question what the books look like,” he said. “How did a lot of smart people get something so wrong?

What WeWork shows "is that some companies should stay private for longer.”

Mr Bundy said there’s a five-to-one margin of companies getting acquired rather than being floated in Silicon Valley.

Afterpay shares advanced nearly 2 per cent to $29.21 on Tuesday. The regulatory risk surrounding the Reserve Bank's review of payments is manageable for Afterpay Touch, says Morgan Stanley, believing the stock "looks oversold on misplaced concerns".

The issue for investors appears to be the future of Afterpay's no-surcharge rule, which prevents merchants from recovering the costs associated with the buy now, pay later juggernaut's systems from customers.
description: A rotation from growth to value is a welcome change for the Australian market, but nobody can say with any confidence if it lasts.
